meanings.def: rude in a way that causes somebody to feel upset or annoyed because it shows a lack of respect
examples: offensive remarks
The programme contains language which some viewers may find offensive.
racially offensive language/comments
offensive to somebody His comments were deeply offensive to a large number of single mothers.
This sort of attitude is very offensive to black people.
This job is stressful enough even without clients being offensive.
The material is patently offensive as measured by the standards for the broadcast medium.
The problem is how to eliminate offensive smells from the processing plant.
What a disgusting smell!
She could smell his foul breath.
The stew looked revolting.

meanings.def: connected with the act of attacking somebody/something
examples: an offensive war
offensive action
He was charged with carrying an offensive weapon.

meanings.def: connected with the team that has control of the ball; connected with the act of scoring points
examples: offensive play
an offensive player/lineman/tackle

meanings.def: a military operation in which large numbers of soldiers, etc. attack another country
examples: an air offensive
They launched the offensive on January 10.

meanings.def: a series of actions aimed at achieving something in a way that attracts a lot of attention
examples: The government has launched a new offensive against crime.
a sales offensive
The public seems unconvinced by their latest charm offensive (= their attempt to make people like them).

meanings.def: to be attacking somebody/something rather than waiting for them to attack you
examples: The Scots were on the offensive for most of the game.
The government is very much on the offensive in the fight against drugs.

meanings.def: to start attacking somebody/something before they start attacking you
examples: She took the offensive, challenging her critics to prove their allegations.

idioms.def: to be attacking somebody/something rather than waiting for them to attack you
examples: The Scots were on the offensive for most of the game.
The government is very much on the offensive in the fight against drugs.

idioms.idiom: go on (to) the offensive | take the offensive
idioms.def: to start attacking somebody/something before they start attacking you
examples: She took the offensive, challenging her critics to prove their allegations.
